newsitem.title: USA: Lawmakers oppose US FCC phone restructuring plans.
newsitem.headline: Lawmakers oppose US FCC phone restructuring plans.

text.p: Key Republican lawmakers on the House Commerce Committee on Thursday took issue with Federal Communications Commission (FCC) plans to restructure telephone access charges.

In particular, FCC proposals to raise federal charges on businesses and residential users who have more than one line were very troubling, committee chairman John McCain of Arizona and communications subcommittee chairman Conrad Burns of Montana said in a letter to FCC Chairman Reed Hundt.
Increasing costs for so-called multiline users is seen as a way of charging Internet users more for phone service.

"Whether the FCC raises Internet connection rates by subjecting Internet connections to access charges or by raising the multiline (charges) for residences and businesses, the bottom line is the same -- rates are going to go up," the letter said.
The letter also said a proposal to tax wireless service providers an extra $1 per month was discriminatory against small businesses.
